author: henrik
post: “In it was painted, in a subtle way, the double portrait of a man” Memorandom of Pierre de Arcis, 1389 The issue is not whether some thought the image was painted but rather if it always has been considered to be subtle. A recently left imprint can still be subtle. No references to a clear image?.
title: A Couple of Terrific Comments About Charles Freeman’s Article

author: henrik
post: Thomas, You referred to the Guadaloupe copy earlier. The two Noalejo (1527) copies are also interesting, page 5: http://www.academicjournals.org/article/article1380797649 Barta%20and%20 Carrascosa.pdf The body image are subtle with fuzzy borders while the text that runs along the entire shroud seem to have survived relatively intact. This higher resolution image (scroll down to the bottom, the image above the two negatives) shows the reverse side of the upper copy from the research paper: http://lasabanaylosescepticos.blogspot.se/2014 05 01 archive.html (The reverse side seems actually to be clearer – but I guess it has to do with the difference in resolution and the large amount of ink that must have permeated) We still get an idea how obscured and blurred the SOT image must have appeared before the fire 1532.
title: Dear Charles Freeman, re the Famous Arnolfini Portrait by Van Eyck
